section.title: 2.2 Form and Morphology
section.content: 2.2 Form and Morphology
section.related-content:
This is the module 2.2 Form and Morphology.
Chemical morphology is the shape and size of a specific body, the texture or topography of a surface and the distribution of phases in a material. In this section we will review the terms and methods used to classify carbon black in its forms as a particle, an aggregate and/or an agglomerate.

section.title: Morphology: Form
section.content: Particles Aggregates Agglomerates Pellets Morphology: Form
section.related-content: Morphology describes the many forms of carbon black from the smallest entity called a particle to the largest we experience as a pellet or bead. Once you have an understanding of the morphology of carbon black then other properties, such as those for aggregates, agglomerates, and pellets will flow from these fundamentals. In producing carbon black we will learn how we can control both particle and aggregate size. However, first let's explore what we mean by the morphological terms we have mentioned.

section.title: Carbon Black Formation
section.content: Carbon Black Formation
section.related-content: A simple way to mimic the lampblack process is to take a porcelain crucible and place it in the flame of a burning candle. The soot or lampblack will form on the surface of the crucible as shown in this drawing. What we have is a hydrocarbon source (the candle wax), a high temperature (the burning of part of the wax as it vaporizes from the wick) and the collection of the lampblack on the surface of the crucible. The crucible simply cools part of the flame before the wax has time to completely burn up into carbon dioxide and water. Now, let us look at the layer very close to the crucible.

section.title: Carbon Black Formation: Details
section.content:
Carbon Black Formation:
Details Expanded View Expand This Area Particles Aggregates Agglomerates
section.related-content:
We will schematically expand the layer so that we can visualize what is happening to the unburned carbon just before it sticks to the surface of the crucible.
The forms of carbon which still contain a little hydrogen have very low vapor pressure. This condenses in to spheres called particles. These particles bump into each other and fuse together to form what is called an aggregate. The chemical bonding within an aggregate between particles is called covalent bonding and is very strong. It is very difficult to break apart an aggregate We will discuss aggregate formation in more detail in the next few slides.
As the aggregates cool off, there is a lack of reacting carbon in this region to form more particles or to cause fusion of two aggregates into a larger one. Also, at this point aggregates come together but do not strongly bond to form agglomerates. The attraction among aggregates in an agglomerate is due to what is called Van der Waal's forces. However, these weak attractions can be overcome with simple mixing of the carbon black in a customer's matrix whether it is water, oil, plastic or rubber. Hence agglomerates break down into aggregates in the customer's matrix.

section.title: Lampblack Aggregate: A Micrograph
section.content:
Lampblack Aggregate:
A Micrograph Not round as in drawings Average made from a range of sizes Aggregate Average = 0.1 mm 0.2mm
section.related-content:
Pictured here is an actual photo of an aggregate of lampblack taken with an electron microscope. We cannot observe the individual particles and the aggregate with our naked eye. All we will see in a carbon black is a small black speck. In this electron micrograph, you will immediately notice that the nodules which make up the aggregate are not exactly round as we will picture them in drawings.
The particles that make up lampblack average around 0.1 micrometer. The particles of the large aggregate in the foreground are in the range of 0.2 micrometer.
Note the much smaller aggregate with much smaller particles in the upper right hand corner of the micrograph that are also part of the distribution of particles that define this carbon black.
When we say that the average is 0.1 micrometer, there is quite a range in the size that makes up this average particle size.

section.title: Carbon Black Particle
section.content: Carbon Black Particle Particle Impacts Surface Area and Chemistry Can be controlled by modern furnace process
section.related-content:
Here is another view of an aggregate of carbon black which has been pictured with different contrast.
It is very important that you are quite clear as to what makes up a particle of carbon black. Again, we picture it here and indicate the diameter by the distance of the arrow on the particle label.
The particle size of the carbon black will directly impact surface area and chemistry, which we will explore later. However, it is important to note that particle size is one of the two (2) most important properties that can be controlled in modern furnace processes.

section.title: Particle Size: Function of Reaction Temperature
section.content: Particle Size: Function of Reaction Temperature How do you control the number of particles that stick together to form an aggregate? How is particle size controlled in a reactor?
section.related-content:
How is particle size controlled in a reactor? Simply stated, it is the reaction temperature that dictates the particle size (and surface area) as we see in the graph here. As the temperature of reaction increases, the particle size decreases. As the particle size decreases, the surface area increases. Well, we are getting ahead of ourselves so we will stick to the form (morphology) for the present.
If this is how you can control particle size then how do you control the number of particles that stick together to from an aggregate? The next slide will illustrate the proposed mechanism

section.title: Aggregate Size: Control with Potassium
section.content:
Aggregate Size:
Control with Potassium K+ +K Repulsion
section.related-content:
As the aggregate forms, particles collide with and stick to it at the high reaction temperature. However, to keep particles from bonding together, kalium (or better know to us as potassium with a symbol of K) is added to the oil before the reaction takes place. This will be illustrated on the next slide.
The potassium ionizes to form a positive ion on the surfaces of the particles and forming aggregates. If a positively charged particle and aggregate approach each other, they are repelled. This repulsion of like charges is similar to how the same poles of two magnets repel each other. As more potassium is added, the more likely the surfaces of both the particle and the forming aggregate will have a positive charge and not bond to each other. This reduces the structure of the carbon black.

section.title: Formation Zone
section.content: Formation Zone Potassium (K) injected with the oil Formation Zone
section.related-content:
First, we add potassium to the oil before it reaches the carbon black formation zone. Typically, the potassium must be in a solution, such as potassium acetate, dissolved in water which is then added to the oil.
The formation zone is where the oil (a hydrocarbon) is cracked by the high temperature and reforms into particles which collide together to make aggregates. Again, the repulsion of positively charge surfaces keep particles from attaching to each other.
Once the aggregates cool slightly they will not continue to bond with each other.

section.title: Structure
section.content: LowModerate Branching Extensive BranchingHigh Permanent Structure Structure
section.related-content:
We have seen in previous slides how to control the number of particles that bond together to form an aggregate. Now, let's see the impact of that control on tests to measure structure.
If you have fewer particles per aggregate then you have less branching and this is called low structure. And with higher number of particles per aggregate, you have high structure or more branching.
When we are talking about the structure resulting from the aggregates, this is called permanent structure. The reason for this is that it is very difficult to break an aggregate due to it's covalent bonds between the particles fused together. With this difficulty comes permanence. This is the structure that most customers will see impacting their application.

section.title: Structure from Agglomeration
section.content:
Structure from Agglomeration
 More pelletizing energy = tighter packing Secondary or Temporary
section.related-content:
Now, let us discuss the temporary structure resulting from agglomerates. As you can see in this illustration, we have identical size and shape aggregates forming an agglomerate. Obviously, we would never have identical aggregates but it helps with the illustration.
As the aggregates come together, they have spaces between them that are larger than the spaces within the aggregates branches. This is the secondary or temporary structure. It is temporary in the sense that it is a function of how much energy is used to form the agglomerate. The more energy added, such as in pelletization, the tighter the packing and hence the less temporary structure. This effect can actually be measured and that is exactly what we will discuss next in the tests used for structure.

section.title: Tests for Structure: Aggregate Branching
section.content:
Disadvantages Tests for Structure:
Aggregate Branching Advantages Quick Precise Automated Machine Requires standard reference black to calibrate Affected by densification history Affected by individual pellet hardness and distribution 1) OAN 2) COAN Measures the amount of oil needed to fill the spaces within agglomerates and aggregates
section.related-content:
Let's look at three tests used to determine the structure of carbon black. Two tests which you will become familiar with are the oil absorption number, O-A-N and the compressed oil absorption number, C-O-A-N.
The O-A-N test measures the amount of oil needed to fill the spaces within aggregates and agglomerates. It is a quick and precise method that uses an automated machine to make this determination. The disadvantages are that the test needs a standard reference black to calibrate. In other words it is not a direct measurement. It is affected by densification as we mentioned earlier when discussing agglomerates and the test can also be impacted to a slight degree by individual pellet hardness and distribution.

section.title: Tests for Structure: Aggregate Branching
section.content:
Tests for Structure:
Aggregate Branching Eliminates Densification History Quick Precise Automated Machine More Steps than OAN More Equipment Advantages Disadvantages 2) COAN Carbon black is subjected to a crush pressure of 24,000psi four times before the test is run.
section.related-content: COAN is the same as OAN except the carbon black is subjected to a crush pressure of 24,000 psi four times before the test is run. This helps eliminate the densification history of the carbon black especially in the pelletizer. The main drawbacks are the extra steps in crushing the carbon black and the equipment used to do this.

section.title: Oil Absorption Number Instrument
section.content: Mixing Blades Oil Absorption Number Instrument
section.related-content:
Many of you have seen this instrument in the plant labs. The OAN instrument is used throughout the world on virtually every carbon black line to determine the structure of carbon black.
The system consists of three key components. There is a precise oil delivery system, a mixing bowl and a torque sensor. The oil is slowly added to the mixing bowl containing a weighed amount of carbon black - usually 20 grams. As the oil fills up the spaces in the aggregates and agglomerates, the torque increases. This is the same as when adding milk to a recipe of pancakes. The dry ingredients absorb the milk as you stir. The mixture becomes stiffer until the excess milk thins out the recipe. In our OAN instrument, a sensor picks up the increase in torque on the mixing blades and cuts the oil addition off when a preset torque is reached.

section.title: Carbon Black Bulk Forms
section.content: Carbon Black Bulk Forms Powder Dry Pellets Wet Pellets Specialty Grades Form as it comes out of the reactors with with some compression for shipping
section.related-content:
The morphology of carbon black which consumers actually see can be either in the form of powder, dry pellets or wet pellets that have been dried. Most rubber grades are wet beads which are pelletized with water and dried in a dryer. This is the form marketed by Himadri. Many specialty grades are powders and dry pellets.
Powder form is how the carbon black comes out of the reactor even though there has usually been some type of compression or densification so that it is easier to package and ship.

section.title: Dry Pellet Form
section.content: Dry Pellet Form Dry Pellets Dry Pellets friable, small pellets easier to handle than powders; less dust Rolled Less dense Easily broken
section.related-content: Dry pellets are carbon black powder that has been rolled in a cylinder so that round pellets have formed by weak forces between the carbon black agglomerates. These pellets tend to be less dense and easily broken. These pellets tend to mix easier in the application of a customer and are preferred by customers who have simple incorporation methods for mixing the carbon black in the liquid or polymer.

section.title: Wet Pellet Form
section.content: Highly densified pellets Best for use in severe bulk handling systems to prevent attrition Moderate to high viscosity systems required for dispersion Wet Pellet Form Wet Beads Wet with water and possibly binder Dried Very hard and can survive severe handling Wet Pellets
section.related-content: Lastly, but most importantly are the wet pellets. “ Wet pellet” is a term which refers to the process of pelletization. We pellets have been formed by densifying the carbon black in a pelletizer where water is added but then dried to a low water content in a dryer. These pellets can be quite hard and survive the most severe handling systems. Also, customers who use these type pellets must have aggressive mixing processes to mix the carbon black into their liquid or polymer. Himadri produces this form of carbon black pellets, so these processes will be discussed in more detail later in the training program.

section.title: Pellet Property Tests
section.content:
Pellet Property Tests Pour Density Fines Content Attrition Pellet Size Distribution Individual Pellet Crush Strength Pellet Hardness Suitability of Bulk Handling, Shipping Final Product
 Measures Carbon Black for:
section.related-content:
There are numerous tests to characterize carbon black pellets. Listed on this slide are typical tests performed for quality control and pre-shipment quality assurance. Each test tells something different about the pellets. These properties can have an impact on handling, shipping and performance in the final product. We will go into a little more detail for pour density and pellet size distribution to complete this module; however, let's briefly describe each of the other tests.
Fines is simply the fraction of the carbon black that will pass through a 125 micron screen after a 5 minute shaking process. Fines can make both handling and incorporating into the final product more difficult. The results are reported in % of the original sample.
Attrition is just how much more fines can be generated over time after the initial fines are removed. In this test the fines are removed and additional shaking is carried on for 15 minutes. The additional fines generated are called the “attrition”. This has implications for shipping and handling. As more fines are generated, the carbon black becomes more difficult to handle and incorporate into the customer's product. The results are report in % of the original sample.
Individual pellet crush strength or pellet hardness gives a good indication as to how easily the product will disperse in our customer's matrix. This test can be performed manually or automatically on a standard size of pellets and the results are reported in grams-force or milli-newtons. The softer the pellet, the easier to incorporate in the customer’s matrix unless too much fines are generated. If too many fines are present, they can float out of the mixed medium such as the rubber, plastic, oil, or water.

section.title: Pour Density
section.content: Low Structure Carbon Black High Structure Carbon Black N358 N326 Pour Density Low Structure : Higher Density
section.related-content:
Let's now apply some of the principles that we have learned earlier in this module to predict the pour density of carbon black.
On the left side is an illustration of a low structure carbon black such as N326. With the lower number of particles per aggregate, the pellets compact more and are more dense.
The right side of the drawing shows how a high structure carbon black will pack. With more particles per aggregate the ability to pack more densely has been reduced. A higher structure carbon black such as an N358 will have a lower pour density than the N326 even though the particle size, and hence, surface areas are similar.

section.title: Pellet Size Distribution
section.content: Pellet Size Distribution Screen Sizes Sieve opening (micron) 10 mesh 2000 18 mesh 1000 35 mesh 500 60 mesh 250 120 mesh 125 Pan (-120 mesh) -125 Mixture of pellet sizes How Big? How Uniform? Visual: How round in each fraction. How much fracture in each fraction.
section.related-content:
The pellet size distribution test tells us how big the pellets are and how uniform are the size of the pellets. In the photo of carbon black pellets above you can see that there is a mixture of pellets of different sizes. The pellet size distribution tests separates these pellets into different size fractions by passing the mixture through different screen sizes as shown above. The test is performed by putting a fixed weight of well-mixed carbon black pellets on a set of decreasing mesh-size screens, shaking the carbon black for a fixed time and finally measuring the amount of carbon black found on each screen. The measurement is reported as the percent fraction of each screen and the remaining fraction in the final collection pan. If we look at each fraction, we can determine the relative amount of round pellets and the relative degree of fractured pellets in the mixture. Large pellets will not incorporate in the customer’s mixture as well as small pellets. Small pellets can become dust in the customer’s factory. Therefore the best pellets are round, average about 500 micron in diameter, and have a narrow size distribution. The pellet size distribution test can give us an impression of how the pelletization process is working and also how the upstream equipment and processes are breaking the pellets upstream of the sampling location.
As we have noted, the properties of pellets are very important to our customers. They may not understand what is happening in our processes to produce pellets with specific characteristics; however, depending on the customer's handling and mixing systems and the matrix in which it is being placed, they are impacted by pellet properties.

section.title: END
section.content: END
section.related-content: This is the end of module 2.2 Form and Morphology.
